name: Dracule Mihawk
nameJapanese: ジュラキュール・ミホーク

keyMoments.description: Mihawk makes his first appearance, arriving at the Baratie on his coffin-shaped boat after pursuing Don Krieg's fleet from the Grand Line.
keyMoments.significance: Introduces one of the most important characters in Zoro's storyline and establishes the power level of Grand Line warriors.

keyMoments.description: Mihawk accepts Zoro's challenge but initially uses only a small cross-shaped pendant dagger, demonstrating the vast gap in their abilities.
keyMoments.significance: Shows Mihawk's confidence and superior skill - he doesn't need his great sword for East Blue opponents.

keyMoments.description: Impressed by Zoro's determination, Mihawk draws his black blade Yoru to properly finish the duel as a sign of respect.
keyMoments.significance: Demonstrates Mihawk's honorable nature and introduces Yoru, the strongest sword in the world.

keyMoments.description: Mihawk spares Zoro's life and encourages him to grow stronger and challenge him again in the future.
keyMoments.significance: Establishes the mentor-rival relationship between Mihawk and Zoro that defines both characters' arcs.

abilities.name: Master Swordsmanship
abilities.description: Mihawk is the world's greatest swordsman, capable of destroying entire fleets and defeating opponents with minimal effort.

abilities.name: Yoru
abilities.description: Mihawk wields Yoru, one of the twelve Supreme Grade swords and the strongest black blade in the world.

abilities.name: Kogatana
abilities.description: A small cross-shaped pendant knife that Mihawk uses against weaker opponents.

relationships.description: Mihawk defeats Zoro but spares his life, becoming the goal Zoro must surpass to achieve his dream.
Mihawk destroyed Krieg's fleet for entertainment and pursued them to the East Blue.

keyMoments.description: Zoro challenges Mihawk to a duel, knowing he's outmatched but unable to pass up the opportunity to test himself against the world's greatest swordsman.
keyMoments.significance: Demonstrates Zoro's unwavering commitment to his dream, even in the face of certain defeat.

keyMoments.description: Flashback to Zoro's childhood promise with Kuina that one of them would become the world's greatest swordsman.
keyMoments.significance: Reveals the emotional foundation of Zoro's dream and why he can never back down from a challenge.

keyMoments.description: Two of Zoro's swords are shattered by Mihawk's Yoru, leaving only the Wado Ichimonji intact.
keyMoments.significance: Shows the importance of sword quality and demonstrates that Wado Ichimonji is special enough to withstand a Supreme Grade blade.

keyMoments.description: Zoro accepts Mihawk's killing blow face-forward, declaring that a scar on the back is a swordsman's shame.
keyMoments.significance: Defines Zoro's code of honor as a swordsman - he would rather die than show his back to an enemy.

keyMoments.description: After his defeat, Zoro makes a solemn vow to Luffy that he will never lose another battle until he defeats Mihawk and becomes the world's greatest swordsman.
keyMoments.significance: One of the most iconic moments in One Piece. This vow becomes the cornerstone of Zoro's character and his loyalty to Luffy.

abilities.name: Santoryu (Three Sword Style)
abilities.description: Zoro's signature three-sword fighting style, though it proves ineffective against Mihawk in this episode.

relationships.description: Mihawk becomes the ultimate goal Zoro must surpass. Despite devastating defeat, Zoro gains Mihawk's respect and acknowledgment.
Zoro's vow to never lose again is made directly to Luffy, deepening their captain-crew bond.
Flashback reveals Zoro's promise to Kuina, which drives his actions in this episode.

keyMoments.description: Appears in Zoro's flashback during his fight with Mihawk, reminding him of their childhood promise.
keyMoments.significance: Her memory and their promise drive Zoro to continue fighting even when facing impossible odds.

relationships.description: Made a promise with Zoro that one of them would become the world's greatest swordsman. Her death motivated Zoro's journey.
Kuina was the daughter of Koushirou, the master of the dojo where Zoro trained.

keyMoments.description: Appears in Zoro's flashback as the dojo master who gave Zoro the Wado Ichimonji after Kuina's death.
keyMoments.significance: Represents Zoro's connection to his past and the origin of his most important sword.

relationships.description: Trained Zoro in swordsmanship and entrusted him with Kuina's sword after her death.
Father of Kuina and master of the dojo where she and Zoro trained.
